author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Democrats Pass a N.Y. House Map That Modestly Benefits Them
description: By exercising restraint in their latest redistricting effort, Democratic lawmakers hope to avoid a lawsuit from Republicans, while still helping their party’s candidates.
content: Democrats in New York adopted a new congressional map on Wednesday, using their supermajorities in the State Legislature to draw district lines that would improve their chances of winning the House majority in November, but not drastically.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich and John Yoon
title: A K-Pop Star’s Lonely Downward Spiral
description: Goo Hara’s life was a struggle from the start. She ended it at 28, isolated and harassed online.
content: The K-pop star looked utterly drained. Her face scrubbed of makeup, Goo Hara, one of South Korea’s most popular musical artists, gazed into the camera during an Instagram livestream from a hotel room in Japan. In a fading voice, she read questions from fans watching from around the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annalee Newitz
title: The Authorities Don’t Need A.I. When Your Neighbors Will Narc on You
description: In “Means of Control” and “The Sentinel State,” modern governments wield high-tech snooping gear while relying on old methods of social surveillance.
content: In 1975, the French philosopher Michel Foucault published “Surveiller et Punir” — “To Surveil and Punish” — a book popularly translated into English as “Discipline and Punish,” about how societies keep their populations in line with minimal violence. At the center of his argument lay the panopticon, a prison designed by the 18th-century political reformer Jeremy Bentham, in which every inmate’s cell door faces a guard tower whose windows are opaque.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: U.S. to Ask Court to Reauthorize Disputed Surveillance Program for a Year
description: As Congress stalls in considering an expiring warrantless surveillance law known as Section 702, the Biden administration has decided not to risk a lapse.
content: The Biden administration is moving to extend a disputed warrantless surveillance program into April 2025, according to officials familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: E-Bike Battery Caused Fire That Killed Young Journalist, Officials Say
description: Fazil Khan, 27, the first New Yorker this year whose death was linked to lithium-ion batteries, was motivated in his work by a strong sense of justice, his friends said.
content: The apartment building fire that killed a young man in Harlem on Friday was caused by the lithium-ion batteries that power e-bikes, the Fire Department said. His was the first death in New York City this year to be linked to the batteries, which were blamed for over 250 fires and 18 deaths last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Eric Lipton, Michael Simon Johnson, Carlos Prieto, Will Reid, Mooj Zadie, Lexie Diao, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Pat McCusker and Alyssa Moxley
title: An Arms Race Quietly Unfolds in Space
description: After warnings that Russia could put a nuclear weapon into orbit, the U.S. is ramping up its space effort.
content: U.S. officials have acknowledged a growing fear that Russia may be trying to put a nuclear weapon into orbit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Kroger, Albertsons and the Biden Administration’s New Antitrust Playbook
description: Price competition isn’t the only thing harmed by monopolies. But can trustbusters prove it?
content: Are Kroger Co. and Albertsons Companies Inc. titans of the grocery business or actually not so big? A court’s answer to that question will be pivotal to whether a merger of the two supermarket chains is allowed to go through.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski
title: Navalny’s Funeral Is Planned for Friday, if Authorities Don’t Block It
description: A scheduled service for the Russian opposition leader will be open to the public, but it is unclear whether the authorities will try to stop people from attending.
content: Aleksei A. Navalny, the Russian opposition leader, will be buried on Friday after a funeral service in Moscow that will be open to the public, his family and aides said on Wednesday, while warning that the authorities could try to prevent people from attending or force the service to be called off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: Older Americans Should Get Another Covid Shot This Spring, C.D.C. Says
description: The agency recommended another round of vaccinations for Americans ages 65 and older.
content: Americans ages 65 and older should receive an additional dose of the latest Covid vaccine this spring, the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: My Dad Cut My Brother Out of His Will. Should I Secretly Split My Inheritance?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on whether to shield a sibling from a painful truth.
content: My 90-year-old father and my younger brother are estranged. I am on good terms with both of them. I’ve agreed to serve as the executor of my father’s will. I’ve seen it, and it cuts out my brother. I don’t know if my brother is aware of this, and I hesitate to bring it up with him for fear of adding more hurt feelings to an already tender situation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lindsay Talbot
title: A Bag That Melds the ’60s, the ’90s and Today
description: A new accessory from Michael Kors reinterprets an archival giraffe print.
content: During his childhood in Merrick, N.Y., Michael Kors took an early interest in fashion: His maternal grandfather worked in the textile industry; his mother, Joan, was a former Revlon model. He’s said that by age 7, he knew his way around Saks Fifth Avenue. In 1981, after spending many of his college nights at Studio 54, Kors, then 21, launched his own label, which epitomized New York’s beau monde. For his spring 1999 collection, he reinterpreted the look of Ali MacGraw’s character, the pool-lounging daughter of wealthy parents, in the 1969 film “Goodbye, Columbus,” inaugurating hooded anorak dresses and introducing playful giraffe spots, a new iteration of his signature animal prints. “I’m always searching for the perfect balance of timelessness and excitement,” the designer says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: New York Times Audio
title: Biden Takes a Hit in Michigan, and Wildfires Spread Across Texas
description: Plus, why the CBD craze is stalling.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Barron, Lynn Levy, Sophia Lanman and Margaret Lyons
title: The Show That Made Me Love Formula One
description: And more sports documentaries to watch right now.
content: To an avid sports fan, the appeal of a documentary film or series about sports is obvious. But our television critic Margaret Lyons argues that being part of a sports fandom is not a prerequisite for enjoying a sports documentary. The world of sports is full of dramatic twists, colorful characters, thrilling highs and agonizing lows — in other words, all the components of a great story. Sports documentaries can also be a way to fall in love with a sport you’ve never watched before. In this episode, Margaret talks about three recent sports documentaries that are worth your attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nate Cohn
title: What Does the Uncommitted Vote in Michigan Mean for 2024?
description: The share of Arab American and Muslim voters is small but could be decisive in a close race.
content: In Tuesday night’s results in Michigan, around one in eight Democrats voted “uncommitted” in the Democratic primary — a protest of the Biden administration’s policies toward Israel and the war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: The Red-Blue Divide Goes Well Beyond Biden and Trump
description: Births and deaths are only part of what makes America turn left or right.
content: One of the major reasons white non-college voters turned to Donald Trump in 2016 and 2020 is the fear of lost white hegemony — that the United States will become a majority-minority nation sometime in the near future.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: oblivious
description: This word has appeared in 138 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word oblivious has appeared 138 times on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Jan. 10 in The New York Times Magazine article “Why Are American Drivers So Deadly?” by Matthew Shaer:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Starbucks and Union Agree to Work Out Framework for Contract Talks
description: In an initial move, the coffeehouse chain said Workers United members would get improved benefits that other employees received in 2022.
content: Starbucks and the union that represents employees in roughly 400 of its U.S. stores announced Tuesday that they were beginning discussions on a “foundational framework” that would help the company reach labor agreements with unionized workers and resolve litigation between the two sides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Cade Metz
title: Inquiry Into Ouster of OpenAI’s Chief Executive Nears End
description: WilmerHale, the law firm investigating Sam Altman, could present its findings to the company’s board as soon as next month. Mr. Altman was reinstated as chief executive.
content: WilmerHale, a prominent U.S. law firm, is close to wrapping up a detailed review of OpenAI’s chief executive, Sam Altman, and his ouster from the artificial intelligence start-up late last year, two people with knowledge of the proceedings said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: Debbie Dingell Breaks Down Michigan’s Primary
description: A Democratic stalwart assesses the “uncommitted” vote protesting President Biden, and says the party must do more to play up his accomplishments.
content: Debbie Dingell is big on tough love.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Micheline Presle, Actress Known for ‘Devil in the Flesh,’ Dies at 101
description: A link to France’s first golden age of cinema, she drew international attention for a 1947 film that created a scandal in France and was banned in Britain for years.
content: Micheline Presle, a subtle and elegant actress who was a last link to the first golden age of French cinema, died on Feb. 21 in Nogent-sur-Marne, a suburb of Paris. She was 101.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Jeffries Suggests Democrats Would Save Johnson From Removal Over Ukraine Aid
description: The House Democratic leader said “a reasonable number” of Democrats would vote to save the Republican speaker if his party sought to oust him over allowing a vote on a foreign aid bill.
content: Representative Hakeem Jeffries, the Democratic leader, said on Wednesday that he believed “a reasonable number” of lawmakers in his party would protect Speaker Mike Johnson from removal from his post if he allowed a vote on a foreign aid bill that includes money for Ukraine and faced a Republican mutiny as a result.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Ole Anderson, Original Member of Four Horsemen Wrestling Team, Dies at 81
description: The professional wrestler fought alongside Arn Anderson, Ric Flair and Tully Blanchard. He later spoke out against the commercialization of the sport.
content: Ole Anderson, a professional wrestler who starred as an original member of the Four Horsemen team in the 1980s and was later critical of the sport’s corporate greed, died on Monday. He was 81.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: A Louis Armstrong Musical Is Coming to Broadway This Fall
description: “A Wonderful World,” featuring Armstrong’s songs, is set to begin previews at Studio 54 in October after previous runs in Miami, New Orleans and Chicago.
content: “A Wonderful World,” a new musical about Louis Armstrong, will have a run on Broadway starting in the fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: To Protect Your Miles, Be Careful How You Book
description: American Airlines recently announced new restrictions on point allocation based on how you book a flight. What does that mean for loyalty members?
content: Earlier this month, American Airlines announced that beginning May 1, it will require travelers to book directly with the airline, partner airlines or “preferred travel agencies” in order to receive points in its loyalty program.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Frieze Los Angeles Opens Amid Attention to Asian Artists
description: Spurred by population growth and new patron support, artists from China, Japan, South Korea and the Philippines are getting more recognition from museums and the market.
content: Last year, Meeson Pae, a Korean American multidisciplinary artist, walked through the Frieze Los Angeles art fair and thought, “One day, I hope to be here.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Suspicious Powder Sent to Offices of Trump Judge and Attorney General
description: An envelope with white powder was found at a courthouse where Justice Arthur F. Engoron has offices. A similar letter was received at the offices of Attorney General Letitia James.
content: Envelopes containing white powder were discovered this week at the offices of two key figures in former President Donald J. Trump’s civil fraud trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gelles and Manuela Andreoni
title: N.Y. State Sues JBS, the Brazilian Beef Giant, Over Its Climate Claims
description: The lawsuit says the meatpacking company has made a series of misleading statements about its environmental efforts.
content: The New York attorney general, Letitia James, on Wednesday sued JBS USA, the American arm of the world’s largest meatpacker, accusing the company of making misleading statements about its efforts to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The lawsuit is a major setback for JBS, which is based in Brazil, as it pursues a listing on the New York Stock Exchange.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: Construction Safety Firm Charged With Faking Training of Worker Who Died
description: The company and 25 people were also charged with running a scheme that falsely certified thousands of workers as having completed required safety training.
content: A construction safety company in New York City and 25 individuals were charged on Wednesday in connection with a yearslong scheme that falsely certified thousands of workers as having completed required safety training, the Manhattan district attorney’s office said. One of the workers the firm claimed to have trained fell to his death at a job site.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins and Vladimir Zivojinovic
title: A Land Once Emptied by War Now Faces a Peacetime Exodus
description: Bosnia is being hit by a combination of a low birthrate and emigration, a trend fueled by ethnic tensions and disgust with corruption.
content: When the Bosnian sheep farmer fled his home in a disintegrating Yugoslavia in 1992, trekking with his family for 40 days to escape the start of a war that would pit neighbor against neighbor, the village he left behind had more than 400 people, two shops and a school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Agrees to Hear Trump’s Immunity Claim, Setting Arguments for April
description: The former president’s trial on charges of plotting to subvert the 2020 election will remain on hold while the justices consider the matter.
content: The Supreme Court on Wednesday agreed to decide whether former President Donald J. Trump is immune from prosecution on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election, further delaying his criminal trial as it considers the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holland Cotter
title: What to See in N.Y.C. Galleries in March
description: This week, Holland Cotter covers the Studio Museum in Harlem’s residency results, Sarah Grilo’s little-seen paintings and Mary Lucier’s experimental and heartfelt video art.
content: This week in Newly Reviewed, Holland Cotter covers the Studio Museum in Harlem’s residency results at MoMA PS1, Sarah Grilo’s little-seen paintings at Galerie Lelong and Mary Lucier’s heartfelt video art at Cristin Tierney Gallery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Leslie Jamison
title: The Mind-Boggling Simplicity of Learning to Say ‘No’
description: Keeping a notebook of every opportunity she declined helped the writer Leslie Jamison realize what matters most.
content: When I was 25, I took a job at a bakery in a small college town in the Midwest. I worked front and back of house, pulling espresso shots at the bar and running into the kitchen to grab my (often burned) sugar cookies from the oven.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Could Swifties or Trekkies Decide the Election?
description: Why political groups are tapping into fandoms.
content: After Emily Sundberg reported in her daily business newsletter, Feed Me, that the Working Families Party is looking to hire a “fandom organizing coordinator,” she got a bunch of emails from readers scoffing at the idea of such a position. It is silly, for example, to imagine organizing devotees of J.R.R. Tolkien via social media for political action. What’s next, “Orcs for Biden”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Netflix Names Dan Lin Its Top Movie Executive
description: The producer behind the streaming company’s new live-actor remake of “Avatar: The Last Airbender” will replace Scott Stuber.
content: Netflix said on Wednesday that the producer Dan Lin would replace Scott Stuber as the streaming company’s top film executive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: A Quiet Town Has One of North America’s Oldest Chinese Temples
description: The Bok Kai Temple, honoring a water god, has stood in Marysville, 40 miles north of Sacramento, since the 1800s.
content: For a brief time in the mid-19th century, one of the biggest cities in California was a place you may never have heard of: Marysville, about 40 miles north of Sacramento.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi, Keith Bradsher and Claire Fu
title: China Expands Scope of ‘State Secrets’ Law in Security Push
description: The legal change, which could further limit access to information, is part of an increasingly hostile environment facing foreign businesses in the country.
content: China passed revisions to an already stringent state secrets law, broadening the scope of the type of information that would be considered a national security risk in the world’s second-largest economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean and Elian Peltier
title: Ghana’s Parliament Passes Anti-Gay Bill With Jail Terms
description: The legislation would sentence those who identify as L.G.B.T.Q. to three years in jail and punish those who promote gay issues as well. It would be among the harshest on the African continent.
content: Ghana’s Parliament on Wednesday passed a bill that imposes jail terms on people who identify as L.G.B.T.Q. or organize gay advocacy groups, measures that Amnesty International called among the harshest on the African continent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carolina Abbott Galvão
title: The Pianist Amaro Freitas Takes His Jazz Somewhere New: The Amazon
description: For his latest album, “Y’Y,” the Brazilian composer looked to inspirations in nature and experiments with prepared pianos.
content: In the northeastern Brazilian state of Pernambuco — a narrow, humid stretch of land where the South American coastline juts out into the Atlantic — fables endure the test of time. “There’s one about the Pajeú, the river which runs through the state,” the jazz composer and pianist Amaro Freitas said on a recent morning, video-calling from his sun-drenched living room in Recife. “It goes like this: Once upon a time, a Brazilian viola was buried in the riverbed. From that moment on, anyone who drank from the stream would become a poet.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Odysseus Moon Lander Heads Into a Cold Lunar Slumber
description: The commercial spacecraft’s builder, Intuitive Machines, released new images from the moon’s surface as the company described plans to try to wake it up in two to three weeks.
content: Soon it will be time to say, “Good night, moon lander.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion
description: In case you need some puzzle help.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson
title: Congressional Leaders Strike a Short-Term Deal to Avert Partial Shutdown
description: Top lawmakers agreed to vote on a temporary funding patch that would allow more time for spending negotiations.
content: Congressional leaders said on Wednesday they had agreed to another short-term stopgap spending bill to head off a partial government shutdown at the end of the week, paving the way for a temporary path out of a stalemate that has repeatedly threatened federal funding over the past six months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter
title: Thursday Briefing: U.N. Warns of Famine in Gaza
description: Plus a protest vote against President Biden.
content: At least a quarter of Gaza’s population is “one step away from famine,” a U.N. humanitarian aid official told the Security Council yesterday. Aid groups say that people are so hungry they are resorting to eating leaves, donkey feed and food scraps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris
title: Publishing Pledged to Diversify. Change Has Been Slow.
description: A new survey shows that more people of color are working in the book business, but the industry remains overwhelmingly white.
content: More than three years after nationwide protests over racial inequality led publishers to promise they would reshape their overwhelmingly white industry, a survey showed they made little progress toward creating a more diverse publishing work force.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: These Cities Aren’t Banning Meat. They Just Want You to Eat More Plants.
description: Meat and dairy production are linked to emissions of methane, a potent greenhouse gas.
content: Amsterdam won’t be giving up its Gouda. Los Angeles eateries will keep serving up combinations of bacon, chicken, egg and blue cheese that are essential to its signature Cobb salads. And Scots can breathe a sigh of relief knowing that Edinburgh has no plans to outlaw haggis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Knight
title: One Way to Preserve Alcatraz? Capture Everything in 3-D.
description: The former prison known as the Rock faces seismic activity, climate change and general deterioration. A wondrous new map could help save it.
content: In May 1946, chaos erupted when six prisoners who were determined to escape from Alcatraz Island overpowered guards and grabbed weapons and keys.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: The World May Be Entering a Much Bloodier Era
description: The wave of coups in the African Sahel is an alarming development
content: War is on the rise everywhere. When the International Institute for Strategic Studies in London published its authoritative Armed Conflict Survey in early December, it counted 183 conflicts globally in 2023 — higher than had been recorded in 30 years. The most remarkable episode of this harrowing new era of global violence is an astounding spate of military takeovers in what has come to be known as the coup belt, stretching uninterrupted across Africa’s Sahel from the Atlantic Ocean to the Red Sea: six countries enduring 11 coup attempts, eight of them successful, since just 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Biden Looks to Change the Conversation on Immigration and Crime
description: The president, saying he is making progress on those issues despite G.O.P. intransigence, appeared intent on pushing back against Republicans who have assailed him and Democrats.
content: For years, Republicans have assailed President Biden and Democrats for policies they say are too lax on curbing immigration and tamping down on violent crime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Richard Lewis, Acerbic Comedian and Character Actor, Dies at 76
description: After rising to prominence for his stand-up act, he became a regular in movies and TV, most recently on “Curb Your Enthusiasm.”
content: Richard Lewis, the stand-up comedian who first achieved fame in the 1970s and ’80s with his trademark acerbic, dark sense of humor, and who later parlayed that quality into an acting career that included movies like “Robin Hood: Men in Tights” and a recurring role as himself on HBO’s “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” died on Tuesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 76.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Why Are Grapes Suddenly Everywhere?
description: Plus: a new dining destination with rooms for the night in the Swedish countryside and more from T’s cultural compendium.
content: Grapes have been associated with pleasure since ancient times, a symbol of Bacchus, the god of wine and revelry. These days, clusters of plummy Concords, oval autumn royals and dusky kyohos are decorating dinner tables, doubling as cornucopian decorations and low-effort snacks. “You can get a beautiful, imperfect drip and drape from grapes,” says the interior stylist Colin King, 35, who overflowed a marble urn with abundant mounds of them for the launch of his furniture collection, a collaboration with the Future Perfect, in New York this past fall. Although he uses green grapes for daytime parties, for evening events he prefers the “moody, sensual vibe” of dark varieties — like the attenuated, oblong moon drops that the artist Laila Gohar, 35, mixed with red globes and flames to form an edible monolith for the recent opening of the Essentiel Antwerp clothing store in New York. The chef Mina Stone, 42 — who runs Mina’s, the cafe at MoMA PS1 in Queens, and is a go-to caterer for art gallery dinners — favors Thomcords, a sweet, seedless hybrid she often serves with dessert to “provide heft and a colorful backdrop” for daintier confections. She also likes to roast grapes alongside seared duck breast. In London, the pastry chef Claire Ptak, the owner of Violet bakery, offers what she calls fragolina cupcakes, named for the fragola (Italian for “strawberry”) grapes that she cooks down, then purées and adds to the buttercream frosting. The fragolas “taste like a berryish Concord,” says Ptak, 49, who tops each cake with a small cluster of fruit. The frosted treats “transport you back to childhood when you take the first bite,” she says, “and then you realize they’re also very grown-up.” — Lauren Joseph
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Goodman
title: How a Vermont Ski Area Roared Back From a Financial Scandal
description: Less than a decade ago, the biggest fraud in ski industry history nearly took down a beloved ski area. But Jay Peak, long known for its powder, has since transformed into a sparkling modern resort.
content: Settling into the first tram of the morning at Vermont’s Jay Peak resort last month, I looked down to see a young boy wearing a neon helmet pressed against the window, his father next to him, as excited as I was to ski the foot of fresh snow. The boy told me that he was 10 years old. I asked him why he liked coming to Jay Peak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Nepo Babies Crowd the Runways
description: The casting craze for celebrity kids hit the big time with the likes of Gigi Hadid and Kendall Jenner. In 2024, the trend is not slowing down.
content: At London Fashion Week, the honor of the final look at the Burberry show didn’t go to a runway legend like Naomi Campbell, Agyness Deyn or Lily Donaldson, all of whom walked in the show. Instead, Maya Wigram, wearing a belted leather field jacket and billowing maxi-kilt, took the lap most models would kill for in her modeling debut.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor, Orlando Mayorquin and Judson Jones
title: Reports of Tornadoes as Severe Storms Move Through Midwest
description: Flights were briefly grounded at O’Hare Airport on Tuesday, and tornado warnings were issued in Ohio on Wednesday morning.
content: A parade of severe weather was marching eastward on Wednesday, hours after parts of the Upper Midwest were hit with strong thunderstorms, damaging winds and numerous reports of tornadoes, leaving thousands without power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pete Wells
title: Writers: Always Pack a Notebook
description: A Times critic didn’t have his laptop when he learned a renowned chef had died. But he did have a stenographer’s pad.
content: Pete Wells, the chief restaurant critic for The New York Times, was on vacation this month when he learned that the renowned chef David Bouley had died.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero and Alejandro Cegarra
title: A Boring Capital for a Young Democracy. Just the Way Residents Like It.
description: The British-designed capital, Belmopan, is bureaucratic and, some say, boring. Some in the city want it to stay that way.
content: Mention Belmopan, Belize’s capital that sits deep in the country’s interior, and many Belizeans will belittle the city as a bastion of pencil-pushing bureaucrats that’s not just dull, but also devoid of nightlife.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Kenny
title: ‘Code 8: Part II’ Review: Helping a Child in Danger
description: In this Netflix sequel, the acting cousins Robbie and Stephen Amell again play gruff men of action — physical and psychic — navigating an urban dystopia.
content: If you didn’t see the 2019 movie “Code 8,” but for some reason decide to take a chance on the sequel, fear not: “Code 8: Part II” begins with a vivid account of a not-too-distant-future where 4 percent of people “possess superhuman abilities” and an authoritarian police force leans hard on robots both two- and four-legged.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Ryan
title: Frequent Marijuana Use May Raise Risk of Heart Attack, Study Suggests
description: A new study analyzed several years of surveys on  increases in marijuana and cannabis consumption.
content: People who frequently smoke marijuana have a higher risk of heart attack and stroke, according to a study published on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: How the Senate G.O.P. Scored a Top Recruit and Widened Its Path to a Majority
description: The recruitment of Larry Hogan in Maryland served as a capstone to months of quiet success for Senate Republicans, after years of recruiting disappointments.
content: Larry Hogan might not be running for Senate this year but for a letter he received in early January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: In an Age of Intercepts, the C.I.A. Makes the Case for Spies
description: Eavesdropping on communications provides limited insight, the agency’s espionage chief argues in a new podcast. Only humans can tell the full story.
content: Intelligence-gathering today relies on electronic eavesdropping on calls and text messages as well as high-resolution satellite images. But in its new podcast, the C.I.A. argues that even in the age of artificial intelligence and ubiquitous intercepts, human sources are more important than ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colette Coleman
title: For a Growing Number of Latinos, Home Buying Is a Family Affair
description: Many are becoming first-time and first-generation homeowners by pooling their family’s resources to buy as a unit.
content: Whenever Danae Vega, 33, took a shower in her Southern California home, it was an ordeal. The pipes were broken, so the water didn’t drain. Each time, she would have to ask her younger brothers to manually remove the water so the next person in the family of eight could take a shower. Demanding that the landlord repair the pipes was not an option. “When we would tell the owner to fix it, he would always threaten us: ‘If I fix it, I’m going to have to include this in raising the rent,’” she said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Protess and Kate Christobek
title: Trump Rebuffed After Asking a Judge to Delay His $454 Million Penalty
description: The former president, who is appealing the penalty in his civil fraud case, offered a bond of only $100 million to pause the judgment.
content: Donald J. Trump on Wednesday lost his initial bid for a New York appeals court to pause the more than $450 million judgment he faces in a civil fraud case, a decision that could expose him to financial peril.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: Watchdog Finds E.U. Border Agency Too Weak to Prevent Migrant Disasters at Sea
description: Investigators looking into the drowning of more than 600 people off Greece say that the border agency known as Frontex cannot fulfill its mission.
content: Eight months after hundreds of migrants died in a capsizing on the Mediterranean, investigators said Wednesday that the European Union’s border agency lacks the ability to prevent future maritime disasters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Miglena Sternadori
title: Fast-Spreading Wildfires in Texas Panhandle Prompt Evacuations
description: One of the wildfires, the Smokehouse Creek fire near the cattle-country town of Canadian, is now the second-largest ever recorded in Texas.
content: The second-largest wildfire on record in Texas raged across 850,000 acres on Wednesday, as firefighters from around the state tried to contain it. The blaze has consumed houses, burned vast ranch lands, killed livestock and forced evacuations across the sparsely populated Texas Panhandle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: As Michigan Votes, Haley Slams Trump in Colorado and Presses Party Officials
description: Ms. Haley, crisscrossing the country in ahead of Super Tuesday next week, sought to pressure the Republican National Committee for transparency over Donald J. Trump’s legal bills.
content: As voting was underway in Michigan, Nikki Haley was delivering her closing pitch to voters further west in Colorado, which votes next week on Super Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘As We Speak’: Rap Music on Trial’ Review: Weaponizing Lyrics in Court
description: Lyrics that contain references to violence have been used as legal evidence, a practice this documentary by J.M. Harper condemns as unfair and prejudicial.
content: Imagine music that you wrote being held against you in a criminal proceeding. In the documentary “As We Speak: Rap Music on Trial,” the Bronx-born rapper Kemba travels around the country and to Britain, interviewing artists and legal experts about how that has been more than a theoretical possibility for rappers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steve Coll
title: Why Authoritarians Like Saddam Hussein Confound U.S. Presidents
description: A C.I.A. capable of making a mistake on the scale of its miss about Iraq’s weapons of mass destruction was not part of Saddam Hussein’s worldview.
content: America committed its worst foreign policy mistake of the post-Cold War era when it invaded Iraq in 2003 to disarm Saddam Hussein of his supposed weapons of mass destruction. The war that followed exacted an appalling price in Iraqi and American lives and resources, and it also empowered Iran, energizing regional proxy conflicts that have entrapped Washington in the Middle East, as the Biden administration has rediscovered painfully.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Philip Galanes
title: Why Can’t My Friend Accept That My Disabled Son Has a Great Life?
description: Put off by pitying displays of concern for her son’s paralysis, a reader wonders how to handle a well-meaning friend whose support misses the mark.
content: Our son was partly paralyzed in a sporting accident as a teenager. Now, years later, he lives a full life — with friends, a job, sports and lots of fun. Still, when we socialize with a certain friend, our son’s disability is her main concern: We get sad eyes, soft touches and pronouncements about how brave we are. I know she means to be supportive, but it makes me uncomfortable. When I respond that his paralysis is not as problematic as she thinks, she goes on and on about how inspirational he is. Sometimes, it casts a pall over the room. Obviously, I am not uncaring about my son’s situation, but he is more than his legs. How should I handle this?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Cain Miller and Margot Sanger-Katz
title: One in Six Abortions Is Done With Pills Prescribed Online, Data Shows
description: The first nationwide count of telehealth abortions includes pills mailed to states with abortion bans by clinicians in states with shield laws.
content: A growing share of abortions is now being administered through telemedicine, with clinicians prescribing mail-order abortion pills after online consultations, according to the first nationwide count of telehealth abortions in the U.S. medical system. At least one in six abortions, around 14,000 a month, was conducted via telehealth from July through September, the most recent months with available data.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Divisions Among Finance Ministers Flare Over Seizing Russian Assets
description: France’s finance minister, Bruno LeMaire, said there was no legal rationale for giving the Russian central bank funds to Ukraine.
content: Divisions among the world’s top economic officials over how to use Russia’s central bank assets to support Ukraine spilled into public view on Wednesday when Bruno LeMaire, France’s finance minister, said that seizing the frozen assets would be a violation of international law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein, Jonathan Weisman and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Biden’s Gaza Challenge Will Persist, but Michigan May Have Been Unique
description: Democratic unease with the president’s handling of the Mideast war will continue to trail him, but his allies hope that no other state on the primary calendar will present the same challenges.
content: President Biden and his allies had reasons for both hope and concern after a Michigan primary election that revealed the party’s painful divisions over the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and confronted him with his largest measure of Democratic opposition to date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daria Mitiuk
title: Ukraine Charges Key Figure in Arms Trade With Corruption
description: A Times investigation showed how the war helped Serhiy Pashinsky rehabilitate a troubled reputation. Now he faces charges related to accusations about his past.
content: A high-profile Ukrainian former politician who has become central to the country’s effort to obtain weapons was arrested on corruption charges earlier this month, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victor Mather
title: Microsoft Word’s Subtle Typeface Change Affected Millions. Did You Notice?
description: A change in Microsoft Word’s default typeface, from Calibri to Aptos, didn’t register for everyone, but fans of typography got excited.
content: When you read — a book, a traffic sign, a billboard, this article — how much do you really notice the letters? If you’re like most people, the answer is probably not at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley C. Ford
title: A Dazzling Humorist Returns With a Deep Dive Into Loss
description: In her new memoir, “Grief Is for People,” Sloane Crosley works through the death of a beloved friend and mentor.
content: Sloane Crosley opens her new book, “Grief Is for People,” with an explanation: “Container first, emotion second.” It’s a four-word guide for the reader: Relieve yourself of the need to understand, and open your mind to the experience of death, suicide and the emotional debris found when you consider the ultimate inevitability.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: ‘The Ally’ Review: Social Justice as a Maddening Hall of Mirrors
description: Itamar Moses’s play offers eloquent arguments on all sides of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. But it doesn’t offer much drama.
content: As this is a trial, let’s start with the facts. Asaf Sternheim, who teaches writing at a university a lot like Penn, is asked by a former student, Baron Prince, to endorse a manifesto. The manifesto seeks justice for Baron’s cousin, Deronte, who was killed by police officers while being stopped for a theft he had nothing to do with.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Travelli and Sameer Yasir
title: Disney to Step Back From India in Mega-Deal with Reliance Industries
description: Mukesh Ambani’s Reliance Industries will control what is left of Disney’s grasp at India’s burgeoning media market.
content: The Walt Disney Company announced on Wednesday a joint venture with India’s biggest conglomerate, Reliance Industries, in an $8.5 billion deal that will create a media powerhouse in the world’s most populous nation and end Disney’s decades-long solo effort to gain a foothold in the market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: McConnell to Step Down as Leader at the End of the Year
description: The long-serving Republican leader said he would step aside from the role at the end of his term but remain in the Senate, acknowledging that his views on national security had put him out of step with his party.
content: Senator Mitch McConnell, the longtime top Senate Republican, said on Wednesday that he would give up his spot as the party’s leader following the November elections, acknowledging that his Reaganite national security views had put him out of step with a party now headed by former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: Companies Were Big on CBD. Not Anymore.
description: A lack of federal regulation and a mishmash of state laws have made selling products featuring the cannabis-derived ingredient not worth the trouble.
content: Just below rows of energy and kombucha drinks at Westside Market, a deli in the Chelsea neighborhood of Manhattan, sit a few glass bottles of Vybes. The drink, which comes in flavors like strawberry lavender and blood orange lime, is made with cannabidiol, more commonly known as CBD.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: In Long-Awaited Testimony, Hunter Biden Assails G.O.P. Impeachment Inquiry
description: The president’s son, who had resisted testifying, condemned Republicans’ efforts to impeach his father and addressed key claims in their case.
content: Hunter Biden, the president’s son, sharply rebuked House Republicans’ impeachment inquiry during a closed-door deposition on Wednesday, condemning their investigation as a “partisan political pursuit” that was based on a “false premise” and fueled by “lies.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Martin, Julia Botero, Christina Djossa, Reva Goldberg, Emily Lang, Daniel Ramirez, Dan Powell, Daniel Jones, Paula Szuchman and Jen Poyant
title: Three Powerful Lessons About Love
description: It’s been 20 years since Daniel Jones started Modern Love as a weekly column in The New York Times. Today, he shares what the job has taught him about love.
content: When Daniel Jones started the Modern Love column in 2004, he opened the call for submissions and hoped the idea would catch on. Twenty years later, over a thousand Modern Love essays have been published in The New York Times, and the column is a trove of real-life love stories.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Four Eye Ointments Pulled Because of Infection Risk
description: Investigators raised concerns about the sterility of the products, which are sold at CVS and Walmart.
content: Four eye ointments sold in stores including Walmart and CVS are being recalled because of a potential risk of eye infections or related harm, after U.S. investigators raised concerns about the potential lack of sterility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Edmund Lee
title: How Apple Used its Car Project to Drive Wider Innovation
description: The tech giant has dropped its plans to develop an electric vehicle, but some of the development at the heart of the effort has helped power other products and services.
content: Has Apple really crashed the car? The tech giant has killed its electric vehicle project as it pivots to artificial intelligence, prompting many observers to declare the venture a major failure for the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Michigan Judge Orders Deposed G.O.P. Leader to Stand Down
description: Kristina Karamo has not said whether she will proceed with holding a dueling presidential nominating convention this weekend.
content: A circuit court judge on Tuesday ordered Kristina Karamo, the deposed leader of the Michigan Republicans, to abandon her efforts to cling to power. But what that means for Saturday, when Ms. Karamo had pledged to hold a dueling presidential nominating convention, remains unclear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yiwen Lu
title: Digital Media Outlets Sue OpenAI for Copyright Infringement
description: Raw Story, AlterNet and The Intercept sued for copyright infringement over the way the ChatGPT creator trains its technology.
content: The media outlets Raw Story, Alternet and The Intercept sued OpenAI for copyright infringement on Wednesday, adding to a growing chorus pushing back against the company’s methods of scraping content off the internet to train its artificial intelligence-powered chatbot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David W. Chen
title: Florida Suspends Bill to Protect ‘Unborn Child’ After I.V.F. Ruling
description: Democrats warned that the proposed legislation, which would allow civil lawsuits over the death of a fetus, would affect fertility treatments.
content: Republican lawmakers in Florida sidelined a bill this week that would allow civil lawsuits over the wrongful death of a fetus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: A Breakaway Region of Moldova Asks Russia for Protection
description: Transnistria declared independence in 1992 but is not recognized internationally. The request by the territory’s legislature could fuel regional tensions as the war in Ukraine rages.
content: A thin sliver of land sandwiched between Ukraine and Moldova asked Russia on Wednesday to provide it with protection, repeating in miniature the highly flammable scenario played out by regions of eastern Ukraine now occupied by Moscow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Happy Leap Day Birthday to Me (See You Again in Four Years)
description: Yes, our driver’s licenses give our real birthday. No, you’re not the first person to joke that we’re too young to drink or drive. A Feb. 29 baby demystifies the quadrennial calendar quirk.
content: My mom tells the story the same way every year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Books Staff
title: 15 New Books Coming in March
description: Memoirs from RuPaul and Christine Blasey Ford; Tana French’s latest crime thriller; new novels by Percival Everett and Téa Obreht — and more.
content: Gonzalez’s sophomore novel follows the Cuban artist Anita de Monte, who is forging a career in New York in the ’80s before her unexpected death, and Raquel Toro, a Puerto Rican art history student at a predominately white college in the ’90s. Through their intertwining stories, Gonzalez explores race, privilege, access and exclusion in the art world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: Sex and Silence: What This Awards Season Tells Us About Hollywood
description: Whether it’s the return of steamy scenes or the lack of political speeches, the road to the Oscars holds a lot of clues about the state of the industry.
content: We’re heading into the final stretch of this awards season, but you needn’t wait until the Oscars on March 10 to begin drawing conclusions about what’s transpired.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: A Botched Execution in Idaho Renews Scrutiny of Lethal Injection
description: Idaho attempted its first execution in 12 years on Wednesday, but medical workers could not tap into a vein on the inmate.
content: Executioners in Idaho abandoned their attempt to use lethal injection on one of the nation’s longest-serving death row inmates on Wednesday after repeated tries to tap into a vein were unsuccessful.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Popcast (Deluxe): Is TikTok Done? 4 Crises Holding the App Back
description: Once addictive and effective, TikTok is struggling with commercialization, a shifting relationship with the music industry and more.
content: This week’s episode of Popcast (Deluxe), the weekly culture roundup show on YouTube hosted by Jon Caramanica and Joe Coscarelli, includes segments on:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Darién Gap Migration Is Halted After Colombia Arrests Boat Captains
description: Boat operators suspended migrant crossings after Colombia arrested two captains. The Biden administration has asked Colombia to do more to stem the flow of people bound for the U.S. border.
content: Migration toward the United States through the dangerous jungle passage known as the Darién Gap has been halted, at least temporarily, following the arrest of two boat captains working for companies that play an essential role in ferrying migrants to the jungle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Nehamas
title: ‘Uncommitted’ Supporters Dance and Celebrate in Dearborn
description: At an election night party, a group that organized a protest against President Biden in Michigan played up the thousands of votes in support of its cause.
content: Long before the final votes had been tallied in Michigan’s Democratic presidential primary race, organizers of a protest movement against President Biden’s support for Israel had declared victory, dancing to the tunes of traditional Palestinian music at a Lebanese restaurant in Dearborn, the center of the state’s Arab American community.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Villarosa and Derek Arthur
title: For This Family, It’s Not ‘Couch Surfing,’ It’s Homelessness
description: Why our definitions of what counts as “unhoused” aren’t adequate.
content: The word “homeless” may conjure up images of shelters and living outdoors. But for millions of Americans, homelessness means sharing a home with multiple families or sleeping on a couch. In this audio essay, the New York Times Magazine contributing writer Linda Villarosa shares her reporting on “doubling up” and makes the case for the government to expand the definition of homelessness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mitch Smith
title: Appeals Court Allows Indiana Ban on Transition Care for Minors to Take Effect
description: A lower court had mostly blocked enforcement of a state law that banned gender-transition care for minors, but a federal appellate court lifted that injunction on Tuesday.
content: Indiana’s ban on hormone treatments and puberty blockers for transgender minors can go into effect, a federal appeals court ruled on Tuesday, undoing a lower court decision last year that had largely blocked the law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Streitfeld
title: How the Media Industry Keeps Losing the Future
description: Roger Fidler tried his best, but the excellent business of journalism is gone for good. Can the idea of “news” survive in a digital world?
content: If the career of Roger Fidler has any meaning, it is this: Sometimes, you can see the future coming but get trampled by it anyway.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Fortini
title: Is There Something Radical About Painting Flowers?
description: Many artists who made their names in figurative work are now creating a different sort of portrait.
content: IN EARLY 2021, Jordan Casteel, the painter known for her tender, exquisitely detailed oil portraits of Black men and other people of color in and around her Harlem community, made two unexpected moves. First, she relocated from New York City to a rural part of the Catskills, a far less populous place where she barely knew anyone. The second move, this one artistic but no less momentous, was that Casteel, 35, began painting pictures of flowers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Breasts, Breasts, Everywhere
description: Saint Laurent and Dior offered two different versions of women’s liberation. Neither was convincing.
content: Enough with the boobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Cameron and Steve Friess
title: Michigan Voters Talk About How the War in Gaza Factored Into Their Decision
description: “I want a cease-fire,” said an 18-year-old who voted for “uncommitted” in the Democratic primary to register discontent with President Biden’s handling of the war in Gaza.
content: When Tuesday began, Mohanad Gazzaley, 18, was not registered to vote, and he had not previously heard of the campaign to vote “uncommitted” in protest of President Biden’s handling of the war in Gaza. Then, standing on the stoop of his parents’ home in Hamtramck, a Detroit suburb, he talked in the early afternoon with a canvasser from the Detroit chapter of the Democratic Socialists of America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: How Visiting the U.S. Border Became a Potent Form of Political Theater
description: The 2,000-mile frontier has become a symbol in American politics as the debate over immigration grows increasingly polarized.
content: Vice President Kamala Harris went to the U.S.-Mexico border soon after she and President Biden took office, even though she had characterized such visits as empty politics just weeks before. President Barack Obama also toured the border during his time in the White House, though he came to see the trips as little more than photo ops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Venice Biennale Says It Will Disregard Petition to Ban Israel
description: Thousands of artists, curators and creative professionals had signed an open letter that cited “ongoing atrocities against Palestinians in Gaza.”
content: In a sign of the deep divisions over the war in Gaza, thousands of artists signed an open letter urging the Venice Biennale to ban “any official representation of Israel” during the art world’s most important event.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellina Moore
title: In Defense of PG-13 Horror
description: Not everyone needs a scary movie that goes to the darkest extremes. Here’s why milder horror films can still pack a punch.
content: It’s nothing new to say that the scariest beasts are those left to the imagination: In the darkened corners of a room, on the ocean floor, in the vacuum of space — terror tends to lurk in the periphery, where it taunts us with what we don’t (or worse, can’t) know. There’s one unfairly maligned horror-movie feature that, when used wisely, can aid with such artful restraint: the humble PG-13 rating.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Food Safety Gaps Let Children Eat Toxic Applesauce
description: Quotation of the Day for Wednesday, February 28, 2024.
content: “Clearly babies and toddlers are paying the price for the industry’s success.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rozina Ali
title: Raised in the West Bank, Shot in Vermont
description: Three months after an attack, its victims grapple with what it means to be Palestinian in America.
content: Kinnan Abdalhamid lived in the United States until he was 2, when his mother, Tamara Tamimi, made her big move to the West Bank. That was where her parents were born, and for her, the idea of a Palestinian home had become a lodestar. In 1988, when she was 15 and protesters had taken to the streets to challenge Israeli occupation in what would become known as the first intifada, she told a local news reporter in Northern California, where she lived at the time, that if she were there, she, too, would be throwing stones at the tanks. “I would feel obligated,” she said. The news segment portrayed Tamara as being “caught between two worlds” — an American one, in which she rehearsed “Bye Bye Birdie” at school, and a Palestinian one, in which she spoke Arabic and struggled to reach relatives back home. She finally moved to the West Bank in 2005, as the region teetered on a precarious peace. She and her husband wanted to raise their child in a world where he could have a community that wasn’t possible in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Kurutz
title: Rumors Swirl Amid Concern Over the Princess of Wales
description: Prince William’s decision to bow out of a planned appearance this week, citing an undisclosed personal matter, fueled feverish speculation about his wife’s health online.
content: On Christmas Day, Catherine, Princess of Wales, attended service at St. Mary Magdalene Church in Sandringham, Norfolk, England, wearing head-to-toe royal blue. She walked to church with her husband, Prince William, and their three children, Prince George, Princess Charlotte and Prince Louis, much like she had in years past.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: In Justin Peck’s ‘Illinoise,’ Dance On and Feel It
description: This narrative dance musical, set to Sufjan Stevens’s album, is a coming-of-age story and a meditation on death, love, community, politics and zombies.
content: Justin Peck was around 17 when he first heard the Sufjan Stevens album “Illinois,” an epic paean to the state, nearly two dozen tracks brimming with orchestral indie rock, dense, lyrical wistfulness and sometimes obscure local history. This listening experience came long before Peck wanted to make dances, before he was even a professional dancer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, Soviet Premier Who Presided Over Economic Chaos, Dies at 94
description: Mr. Ryzhkov, who ascended to the Soviet Union’s second most powerful post in 1985, took much of the blame for the economic collapse that led to the country’s dissolution in 1991.
content: Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, a premier of the Soviet Union who in 1990 took the brunt of the blame for economic chaos that engulfed the last years of Communist rule, leading to the nation’s political collapse and the end of the Cold War, has died. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Tanis
title: This 3-Course Menu Lets You Prep Ahead and Enjoy the Party
description: These recipes from David Tanis — flatbreads rubbed with za’atar, slow-cooked lamb and a gorgeous gluten-free walnut cake — get even better with time.
content: Having friends over for dinner tomorrow? Do yourself a favor and make everything today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: Review: Diasporic History, in Which Motion Is the Message
description: The Afro-Colombian company Sankofa Danzafro presents “Behind the South: Dances for Manuel” at the Joyce Theater.
content: The people are on the run, crouching, protecting their heads with their hands. The people are fighting back, picking up and throwing objects. Some are struck down, but figures in white walk calmly among them: ancestors, spirits. The people are not alone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: The Supreme Court Will Hear Trump’s Immunity Claim in April
description: Also, fast-spreading wildfires prompt evacuations in Texas. Here’s the latest at the end of Wednesday.
content: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether Donald Trump is immune from prosecution on charges of plotting to overturn the 2020 election. The justices scheduled arguments for the week of April 22, putting trial proceedings on pause at least until then.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Orlando Mayorquin
title: Death of David Gail, ‘Port Charles’ Star, Was Drug Related, Publicist Says
description: The 58-year-old actor, who was also on “Beverly Hills, 90210,” died last month in a Tampa, Fla., hospital days after going into cardiac arrest.
content: David Gail, the “Port Charles” and “Beverly Hills, 90210” actor who died in a Tampa, Fla. hospital on Jan. 16, had been intoxicated from a mix of drugs and alcohol that caused him to go into cardiac arrest, his publicist said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Calum Marsh
title: Between ‘Star Wars’ Trilogies, a Golden Age of Video Games
description: A remastered version of Star Wars: Dark Forces reminds gamers of a period in the 1990s when LucasArts could take risks with cherished intellectual property.
content: Though it sometimes feels as if there is a new “Star Wars” installment every couple of months, there was a time when all that fans of George Lucas’s sci-fi universe had were three movies and a lot of imagination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Andrew Higgins
title: Trump to Meet Next Week With Orban, Hungary’s Leader
description: The former president has long been aligned with Hungary’s right-wing prime minister, who has built ties to the conservative movement in the United States.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump will meet privately with Viktor Orban, the prime minister of Hungary, at Mr. Trump’s club in Florida next week, according to a person briefed on the plans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Jones Jr
title: The Essential James Baldwin
description: He wrote with the kind of clarity that was as comforting as it was chastising. Here’s where to start.
content: James Baldwin would have turned 100 on Aug. 2 this year. His final works were published almost 40 years ago, just two years before his death in 1987. Yet his writing is as imperative as ever. He wrote with the kind of moral vision that was as comforting as it was chastising — almost surely the influence of the pulpit he once occupied as a child preacher in his native Harlem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: Center for Public Integrity Weighs Merger or Shutdown Amid Dire Financial Straits
description: The nonprofit had a budget shortfall of roughly $2.5 million last year amid a difficult market for fund-raising.
content: The Center for Public Integrity, one of the oldest and most storied nonprofit newsrooms in the United States, is considering merging with a competitor or shutting down amid turmoil in its top ranks and financial difficulties that have significantly sapped its reserves, according to two people with knowledge of the organization’s inner workings.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe
title: Biden Acts to Stop Sales of Sensitive Personal Data to China and Russia
description: In an attempt to limit blackmail and other harm, he issued an executive order asking the Justice Department to write rules restricting sales to six countries.
content: President Biden issued an executive order Wednesday seeking to restrict the sale of sensitive American data to China, Russia and four more countries, a first-of-its-kind attempt to keep personally identifying information from being obtained for blackmail, scams or other harm.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Parasite’s Place
description: In his New York Times debut, Greg Snitkin has finally made it.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: Arab American Fury Toward Biden
description: If alarms weren’t already sounding in the Biden campaign, now they have to be.
content: On Monday, at a hip Arab coffee shop in Dearborn, Mich., Nihad Awad, a co-founder and the national executive director of the Council on American-Islamic Relations, or CAIR, told me that as a Palestinian American Muslim who voted for Joe Biden in 2020, he feels “betrayed bitterly” over the administration’s position on the war in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: Seeking to Unsettle Russia, Macron Provokes Allies
description: The French president’s openness to Western troops in Ukraine signaled a quest for military resolve. But some allies felt blindsided.
content: With his jolting unexpected statement that sending Western troops to Ukraine “should not be ruled out,” President Emmanuel Macron of France has shattered a taboo, ignited debate, spread dismay among allies and forced a reckoning on Europe’s future.
source.name: The New York Times

description: A letter from moms whose children have a life-threatening illness. Also: Regulating social media; sanctions; politics and I.V.F.; a house full of memories.
content: To the Editor:

author: By The Learning Network
title: Point of No Return
description: Tell us a story, real or made up, that is inspired by this image.
content: Use your imagination to write the opening of a short story or poem inspired by this image or, describe a memory from your own life that this photo makes you think of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran’s Parliament Election 2024: What You Need to Know
description: Iran is holding Parliament elections on March 1, the first general vote since an uprising swept across the country in 2022 calling for an end to the Islamic Republic’s rule.
content: Iran is holding parliamentary elections on March 1, the first general vote since an uprising, led by women and girls, swept across the country in 2022, calling for an end to the Islamic Republic’s rule. The government violently crushed the protests, but demands for change endure and many Iranians view boycotting the vote as an act of protest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle
title: Who Should Pay for Dates?
description: Men still tend to pick up the check more than women. Is that the way it should be? Or is it a tradition that needs to go?
content: Do you ever go on dates? Do your friends? If so, who pays? And how do both parties decide who should?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: Israel Is Losing Its Greatest Asset: Acceptance
description: Israel’s very legitimacy is being undermined by the enormous casualties in Gaza and its government’s failure to provide a credible postwar plan.
content: I’ve spent the past few days traveling from New Delhi to Dubai and Amman, and I have an urgent message to deliver to President Biden and the Israeli people: I am seeing the increasingly rapid erosion of Israel’s standing among friendly nations — a level of acceptance and legitimacy that was painstakingly built up over decades. And if Biden is not careful, America’s global standing will plummet right along with Israel’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: Donna Summer’s Estate Sues Ye for Sampling ‘I Feel Love’
description: The estate said it had denied a clearance request by Ty Dolla Sign and the rapper once known as Kanye West, who then used the song on their new album, “Vultures 1.”
content: When Ye and Ty Dolla Sign asked last month for permission to sample Donna Summer’s 1977 song “I Feel Love,” the disco singer’s estate firmly told them no. Yet when their joint LP, “Vultures 1,” was released weeks ago, a song with strong similarities to Summer’s famous tune was there on the track list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: When Hot Bacon Meets Sliced Brussels Sprouts, Salad Happens
description: A hot bacon dressing, a crispy-edged fried egg and sliced brussels sprouts star in this meal-worthy take on a Southern classic.
content: The first time I heard a friend praising “wilted salad,” the memories came flooding back. They were not entirely good.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee, Hwaida Saad and Michael Levenson
title: As U.N. Warns of Famine in Gaza, Cease-Fire Remains Elusive
description: With the approach of Ramadan, as well as protests by hostage families and a threatened Palestinian march on the Aqsa mosque, pressure is rising to reach a deal.
content: A top Hamas official on Wednesday appeared to raise the stakes for a cease-fire in the Gaza Strip, saying the militant group was ready to continue fighting and calling on Palestinians to defy Israeli restrictions and march to the Aqsa mosque in Jerusalem to pray at the start of Ramadan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Felder
title: Colette’s Sarah Andelman Is Back With Another Idea
description: The founder of the pioneering Parisian concept store curates a new space with Le Bon Marché.
content: As creative director of Colette, the influential Paris store she founded with her mother, Colette Roussaux, Sarah Andelman created an acclaimed hub of all sorts of distinctive items that were frequently quirky and uniformly stylish.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein and Shane Goldmacher
title: Michigan Primary Takeaways: ‘Uncommitted’ Makes Itself Heard
description: President Biden endured a protest vote, Donald Trump fended off Nikki Haley again, and both may face challenges with their party coalitions as they start to look toward November.
content: Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Donald J. Trump won Michigan’s primary elections on Tuesday as the president and his predecessor hurtle toward a rematch in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Lawrence K. Altman, M.D
title: Biden’s Doctor Says He Is ‘Fit for Duty’ After Physical and Neurological Exam
description: President Biden, the oldest president in the country’s history, is facing concerns over his age as he campaigns for a second term.
content: President Biden on Wednesday was declared “fit for duty” by his longtime doctor, who said that the president had undergone an “extremely detailed” neurological exam that did not turn up evidence of stroke, neurological disorders or Parkinson’s disease.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Rattner
title: What Trump Would Do to Our Economy
description: While Trump’s economic policy had serious flaws in his first term, the prospect of what he could do in a second term is frightening.
content: Much to fear about another Donald Trump presidency: The existential threat to U.S. democracy. The potential abandonment of traditional allies in Europe and elsewhere. The cozying up to dictators like Vladimir Putin. And the danger Mr. Trump poses to our strong economy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kayla Guo
title: Senate Republican Blocks Bill to Protect I.V.F. Treatment
description: Republicans, many of whom have said they support access to the treatment, have argued that it should be left to states to ensure its legality after an Alabama court ruled that frozen embryos were children.
content: A Republican senator on Wednesday blocked quick passage of a bill that would establish federal protections for in vitro fertilization and other fertility treatments in the wake of a ruling by the Alabama Supreme Court that frozen embryos should be considered children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: In ‘Elsbeth,’ a Quirky Side Character Becomes a Quirky Lead
description: This CBS procedural is new, but its star, Carrie Preston, has been playing the central character for almost 14 years.
content: While filming the new crime show “Elsbeth” in an Upper West Side apartment in January, Carrie Preston, playing the title character, tentatively patted the guest star Peter Grosz on the arm. The combination of the gesture and Elsbeth’s hesitant expression made the attempt at comfort come across as simultaneously awkward and funny — and unmistakably true to the consistently awkward, funny Elsbeth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: Another Chinese Property Giant Faces a Creditor Who Wants It Dismantled
description: Country Garden was once China’s biggest developer but ran out of money. A lender is taking it to court in Hong Kong, a sign of continuing market distress.
content: Country Garden, China’s largest real estate developer as recently as 2022, said on Wednesday that a creditor had asked a Hong Kong court to liquidate its operations and pay off lenders, in the latest sign that China’s housing crisis continues unabated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: In Fight Over Bump Stock Ban, Lawyers Take Aim at Administrative State
description: The Supreme Court will hear arguments on Wednesday about the Trump administration rule put in place by the A.T.F. after the Las Vegas massacre.
content: A simple device that speeds up a semiautomatic weapon’s rate of fire is at the center of a case that could cast a shadow over a government agency’s ability to regulate firearms.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abbie VanSickle
title: Supreme Court Appears Split Over Ban on Bump Stocks Enacted Under Trump
description: In a wide-ranging argument, the justices wrestled with the mechanics of gun triggers and the larger implications of the ban both for bump stock owners and the public.
content: The Supreme Court wrestled on Wednesday over whether the Trump administration acted lawfully in enacting a ban on bump stocks after one of the deadliest mass shootings in U.S. history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2 Million Homes in Missouri, California and the District of Columbia
description: An 1896 Beaux-Arts mansion in St. Louis, a Spanish-style home in Pasadena and a 1923 stone house in Washington.
content: This house was built for Lewis Dozier, a commercial baker whose business became part of Nabisco. Mr. Dozier, a member of several social clubs, loved to entertain, and his house has a basement-level ballroom and a second-floor musician’s gallery. The sellers, who bought the house in 1996, have spent decades restoring it to its original glory, repairing and refinishing woodwork and plaster, and replacing the electrical and HVAC systems, as well as the roof.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen and Tripp Mickle
title: Behind Apple’s Doomed Car Project: False Starts and Wrong Turns
description: Internal disagreements over the direction of the Apple car led the effort to sputter for years before it was canceled this week.
content: For the last decade, many Apple employees working on the company’s secretive car project, internally code-named Titan, had a less flattering name for it: the Titanic disaster. They knew the project was likely to fail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: A Creamy One-Pot Pasta That Pretends It’s Risotto
description: The velvety texture of this chicken-and-mushroom pasta comes from gradually adding broth and wine and stirring gently.
content: The secret to the silkiest pasta sauces is not oil, cheese or even copious amounts of butter and cream. It’s the starchy water the pasta cooks in, which, when added back to the pan after draining, binds and melds the ingredients during their final simmer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Wednesday Briefing
description: Hamas denies that a cease-fire is near.
content: Hamas officials said yesterday that there had been no breakthrough in talks to pause the war in Gaza and free the remaining hostages there, a day after President Biden said he hoped that a cease-fire would start in a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs and Colbi Edmonds
title: U.S. Airman’s Winding Path Ended in Self-Immolation to Protest Israel
description: Aaron Bushnell, the cyberdefense operations specialist who lit himself on fire to protest Israel’s killing of Palestinians, had left an isolated Christian community for the Air Force before turning to activism.
content: Dressed in his U.S. Air Force uniform, Aaron Bushnell walked up to the Israeli embassy in Washington one afternoon this week and calmly described his intention to “engage in an extreme act of protest” against Israel’s military offensive in Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilya Lipkin and Hisato Tasaka
title: Outdoorsy Men’s Wear That Suits the City Too
description: When out for adventure, whether hiking a trail or navigating the sidewalk, it helps to look the part.
source.name: The New York Times
