description: Corrections that appeared in print on Wednesday, Feb. 28, 2024.
content: An article on Sunday about the Conservative Political Action Conference’s top pick for former President Donald Trump’s running mate, misspelled the name of a census-designated place in Maryland. It is Silver Spring, Md., not Silver Springs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: The Sputtering Effort to Persuade Migrants to Leave New York
description: A $25 million program aims to relocate migrants in other counties. But many don’t want to make the move.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. Today we’ll find out about a $25 million program that’s struggling to relocate migrant families in New York City. We’ll also get details on the proposed congressional map for New York State that Democrats hope will let them recapture the House in November.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dana Rubinstein and Jeffery C. Mays
title: Eric Adams Wants to Deport Migrants Who Are Accused of Serious Crimes
description: Democratic leaders of the City Council said they had no intention of changing New York City’s sanctuary laws to allow Mayor Adams to have his way.
content: For years, New York City leaders have relished the status of being a so-called sanctuary city, where local law enforcement cooperation with federal immigration officials is limited.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: Citing Progress at Rikers, Judge Says New York Is No Longer in Contempt
description: The city Correction Department has improved its tracking of use-of-force cases at Rikers Island and is working more effectively with the monitor who oversees the jail, a judge found.
content: A federal judge in New York has lifted a contempt of court order against the city Correction Department, saying the agency has made progress in tracking cases where correction officers use excessive force at the Rikers Island jail complex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Pope Francis Undergoes ‘Diagnostic Tests’ in Rome Hospital
description: The hospital visit, though short, revived concerns about the health of the 87-year-old pontiff.
content: Pope Francis, who has had a mild flu in recent days, was taken to a hospital in downtown Rome on Wednesday, reviving concerns about the 87-year-old pontiff’s health. The Vatican said in a statement that he had gone for “some diagnostic tests,” but did not offer details about a visit that lasted less than an hour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Alabama Republicans Scramble in an Effort to Pass an I.V.F. Shield Law
description: The urgency underscores the bind for the party, which has long maintained that life begins at conception but must now reconcile that stance with broad support for I.V.F.
content: Alabama lawmakers on Wednesday raced to protect the routine practice of in vitro fertilization, moving to assuage families and fertility clinics alarmed by a recent State Supreme Court ruling that found that frozen embryos should be considered children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Philadelphia Orchestra’s Home to Be Renamed Marian Anderson Hall
description: Because of a $25 million gift, the venue, Verizon Hall, will be renamed to honor Anderson, a pioneering Black opera singer.
content: Marian Anderson, the renowned contralto and civil rights figure who broke racial barriers in the arts and helped pave the way for other Black artists, is being honored in her hometown, Philadelphia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Holly Burns
title: First, a Cancer Diagnosis. Then a Split-Second Decision About Fertility.
description: Young women who find out they have breast cancer often have a very short window to make lifelong decisions about their futures.
content: Two weeks before her 23rd birthday, Roshni Kamta was diagnosed with stage 2 breast cancer. That was the first shock. The second came a few days later, when she found out that the chemotherapy that would save her life might prevent her from having children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Chides Biden for Talking About Gaza While Eating Ice Cream
description: “Not the most dignified way to deliver world-changing news,” Michael Kosta said on Tuesday’s “Daily Show.’
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Long Covid May Lead to Measurable Cognitive Decline, Study Finds
description: People with long Covid symptoms scored slightly lower on a cognitive test than people who had recovered. But long Covid patients who eventually got better scored as well as those whose symptoms did not last long.
content: Long Covid may lead to measurable cognitive decline, especially in the ability to remember, reason and plan, a large new study suggests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nina Siegal
title: Surrealism Is 100. The World’s Still Surreal.
description: Exhibitions around the world are celebrating the art movement’s centennial and asking whether our crazy dreams can still set us free.
content: This is not an article. It’s a fish in the shape of a piano, floating in a clear blue sky, seen through a keyhole.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ligaya Mishan
title: An Easy Way to Elevate Your Grapes
description: The unassuming fruit can reveal so many layers when you give them a little love.
content: Grapes are half snack, half compulsion. Bunched as if just snipped from the vine, skins taut and shining, they are always a crowd, a party unto themselves. There is power in numbers, because if you eat just one, the pleasure is too brief: A burst on the tongue, a spike of sugar in the blood and it’s over. It’s more gush than chew, closer to sipping than eating. Grapes are nothing in isolation. You pop them by the handful, one after another, until you lose count.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eva Wolchover
title: In a Novelist’s Hands, a Herstory of England Is Delicious — but Not Sweet
description: In “Normal Women,” Philippa Gregory gives us nine centuries of real-life heroines, murderers, boxers and brides.
content: Twenty-odd years ago Philippa Gregory plucked Anne Boleyn’s sister, Mary, from historical obscurity, gave her a sexy story of her own and helped set off a mania for Tudor fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Nikki Haley’s Last Ditch
description: The former South Carolina governor has good reasons to fight on.
content: William of Orange was chief magistrate of the Dutch Republic when, during a seemingly hopeless defense against English and French attackers in 1672, he was offered terms he shouldn’t have been able to refuse: to capitulate in exchange for becoming its sovereign prince.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Defeats Haley in Michigan, His Sixth Straight Victory
description: Nikki Haley, who has the campaign cash to keep going, has said she intends to stay in the race at least through Super Tuesday on March 5.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump won Michigan’s Republican presidential primary election on Tuesday, moving closer to a general election rematch against President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian X. Chen
title: Streaming Prices Keep Going Up. Here’s How to Manage Subscriptions.
description: Canceling is simple. The tough part is remembering to do it.
content: The dream of streaming — watch what you want, whenever you want, for a sliver of the price of cable! — is coming to an end.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Tadepalli
title: We Need to Read the Forgotten Geniuses, Not Rescue Them
description: The literary canon is constantly evolving — and critics’ often-frustrating kvetching about reissues is a key part of that evolution.
content: It is a truth universally acknowledged that literary critics are the most annoying people in the world. They’re elitist, or undignified. They’re divisive. They’re snobs. Their profession is, in fact, dead, and has been for decades. And upon realizing that they are irrelevant, they take themselves way too seriously.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter
title: France Moves Closer to Enshrining Abortion Access in Its Constitution
description: The vote by lawmakers comes after supporters of the measure in France were galvanized by the U.S. Supreme Court’s decision overturning Roe v. Wade.
content: France took a step closer to enshrining access to abortion in its Constitution, after senators backed a bill on Wednesday to include it as a “guaranteed freedom.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Prince Harry Loses Legal Challenge Over Security Downgrade
description: Harry had hoped to overturn a government decision to reduce his police protection after he stepped back from royal duties in 2020.
content: Prince Harry lost a long-running legal battle over the downgrading of his security in Britain, as a High Court judge ruled on Wednesday that the British government was entitled to change the level of police protection for a member of the royal family who was no longer carrying out official duties.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: F.A.A. Gives Boeing 90 Days to Develop Plan to Address Quality-Control Issues
description: The announcement came after the agency’s administrator met on Tuesday with Boeing officials, including the company’s chief executive, to discuss safety.
content: The Federal Aviation Administration said on Wednesday that it had asked Boeing to provide the agency with a “comprehensive action plan” to address quality-control issues within 90 days, the regulator’s latest push for safety improvements after a panel came off a Boeing 737 Max 9 jet in flight in early January.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: The SAT and the Supreme Court
description: The future of admissions at selective colleges and high schools has suddenly become clearer.
content: After the Supreme Court banned race-based affirmative action last year, many people in higher education worried that it would be only the first in a series of decisions that reduced diversity at selective schools. In particular, university administrators and professors thought the court might soon ban admissions policies that gave applicants credit for overcoming poverty. Such class-based policies disproportionately help Black, Hispanic and Native students.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simbarashe Cha
title: Fashion at Full Throttle
description: Flashes of red in the crowds outside shows and a surprise appearance by Ye gave Milan Fashion Week a high-adrenaline feel.
content: People at Milan Fashion Week usually go big with their outfits, often by incorporating bold prints or visible logos or some combination of the two. This season, both off and on runways, many achieved an outsize presence by wearing red, shades of which were abundant in the streets and incorporated into the collections of brands like MM6 Maison Margiela and Jil Sander. The color’s prevalence harked back to 1980s action films and their copious red sports cars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Immunity for ‘Troubles’ Violence Violates Human Rights, Belfast Court Rules
description: A judge said a new British law aiming to foster reconciliation over decades of sectarian conflict in Northern Ireland would breach the European Convention on Human Rights.
content: A Belfast court ruled on Wednesday that a new British law granting people immunity from prosecution for crimes committed during Northern Ireland’s bloody sectarian conflict — known as the Troubles — would be a breach of human rights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Back From War, Reserve Soldiers Set Their Sights on Israel’s Politics as Usual
description: Inspired by the unity they experienced in the military, thousands of reservists returning from the front line in Gaza are organizing for political change.
content: Gathered this month around a campfire on the edge of a forest in central Israel, the soldiers planned their next mission: saving their deeply divided country from itself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aaron Boxerman, Hwaida Saad, Raja Abdulrahim and Michael Levenson
title: Hamas Rejects Cease-Fire Proposal, Dashing Biden’s Hopes of Near Term Deal
description: A day after President Biden suggested there could be a deal as soon as Monday, a Hamas official indicated the group would not trade Israeli troops held hostage for Palestinians imprisoned for terrorism.
content: Hamas officials said on Tuesday that there had been no breakthrough in the mediated talks with Israel aimed at pausing the war and freeing the remaining hostages in the Gaza Strip, one day after President Biden said he was hopeful that a cease-fire would be in place by next week.
source.name: The New York Times
